Posts.Title: Results Are In :)

Posts.Title: Worried Sick

Posts.Content: Hi Frillyflower  So sorry about your diagnosis, but you have found a lovely safe and kind place with this site to ask questions and get support. Just one thought from me on private health care.  My father (who used to be a hospital consultant) advised me against it for my first cancer, if your treatment plan involves complex, long surgery. Exactly the same surgeons operate in the NHS as the private sector. So the quality is the same. But the difference is if anything goes wrong.  If you are in a NHS hospital you will have all the other specialists on hand. Not nice to think about, and Im just about to have a long operation myself. But it is reassuring to know.  And the NHS cancer care is fantastic (mostly) And as everyone has told you, what you are feeling is a natural reaction. It will get better once you have a plan for the next stage, and can focus on that xxx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Oh ali owl, so sorry hun to hear such rubbish news. Big [[[[[hugs]]]]] from me. xxx
Posts.Title: PALB2

Posts.Content: Hi Violetsniff - so sorry about your mum, that must have been awful for her and you xxx I asked my surgeon if I could have the genetic testing and was referred and had the test at the start of the month (get my results in July as its a very detailed testing process).   If you are interested, do go and speak to your GP, or one of the BCNs.   I think I got referred as we had 4 breast cancers in my immediate family 1st and 2nd relatives, and we all were under 45 at first diagnosis. The BRCA 1 and 2 mutated genes are fairly rare <1% in the general population, I think. So for most of us even with a strong family history the cause is never known.  Just flipping unlucky xxx

Posts.Content: Hi A68 This is an immensely stressful time for you so try to keep busy - as others have said  If its helpful my surgeon said part of my lump was a "radial scar".  Its a type of cyst (I had no idea what he meant and had to google it). They are benign (not cancer).  Best to prepare mentally for all possible outcomes. Good luck xxx

Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results and have had appointment letter .

Posts.Content: Hi Madagascar   as Leolady56 says, welcome to this forum. I was recently genetically tested for breast cancer but they only looked for the mutations of BRAC1 and  BRAC2; I  was not positive for either. But they didnt test for Palb2 - my genetics nurse told me they could not go beyond BRAC1/2 yet. As Leolady56 says, there may be other ladies that come along with experience of this.  But if its risk reducing surgery they want to do, I would discuss with your medical team the urgency of such a major decision before you have had time to consider the risk and benefits.  BRAC1 and BRAC2 mutant genes have well evidence risk factors associated with them. But I dont know about Palb2. Do speak to your medical team and BCN nurse as they need to give you the information to help you make this decision. And it is always your decision.  Hugs from me too xx .
Posts.Title: Palb2

Posts.Content: Hi Scootergirl  I had a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction (silicon implant)  17 years ago. My surgeon at the time said it should last around 10-15 years.  Mine is still okay, but getting harder.  In am now back on the breast cancer train and had an operation to remove a lump in my good breast on 16 Feb. Im still waiting for the results of the pathology from that one to determine next stage of treatment (results next Wednesday as they have been delayed - another story). At the appropriate point, I plan to ask my surgeon about my foob and how much longer it might last and what they usual do (ie  if eventually it will need replacing and how that might happen). I will tell you what he says.. I think your GP is being unfair. Your implant is not purely cosmetic. Its to help you deal with the devastating affects of this dreadful disease. Looking at it will be a daily reminder of what you went through in 1997.  Mine is a dome shape but looks perfectly normal in a bra.  I would write back to them setting out your concerns and as others say, with any information that is useful. I still have the consent form I had to sign for my implant which is clear that they are not 'lifetime devises and revision surgery may be needed'.  The decision about whether you want to have further surgery if that is needed, must be up to you. But if your implant has moved, than surely the NHS should offer that option.   Sorry this is long, but your post prompted a reaction from me and I am happy to help in any way.  Just a thought, it might be worth ringing the breast caner nurse team in your local hospital to see what they think. There will be a general number and they may have dealt with similar cases before. xx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer implant problem

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Dear lovely ladies - your posts have motivated me to do something today as I woke up feeling pretty low and angry with myself.  Have just put Waling back to happiness on you tube and it has given me a big smile on my face.  Needed that kick in the butt!  And to dust off my big boots as well as big pants  Felt down as I got a call from my surgeon's secretary at just before 4pm (Friday)  to say he had a cancellation for Monday for my lymph nodes operation (had a WLE in Feb, results from that delayed). My first reaction was i cant let work down, its too short notice.  So I said I couldnt make it: next appointment is not until 16 April given Easter.  Rang my friend, who said put yourself first, ring them back immediately and say yes.  By the time I'd done this - it was too late, nuclear medicine had gone home.  So it now means a) I have to wait longer for the result of this stage; b) it  will delay my mastectomy and reconstruction ops; and c) it will probably put my holiday at risk, big grrr.  Fizzing mad at myself, but whats done is done.  So time for some positive feet to be put forward .....  Hope anyone who can  gets some fresh air this weekend even if its just sticking your head out of the window to see spring starting to struggling through. And thanks jmp for the fab 1960 and 70s children's TV photos, thats my era.  Now one more quick burst of Helen Shapiro before I jump into action  No reply needed - just needed to externalize my silly thoughts

Lots of coffee and cake stops helped  Here are some picks from two days walking round this fabulous city, with some of my walking pals. xx. Jacmatholmad you were absolutely right!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Flossie25 - all good with me today with the pre-op, thanks (bit knackered though with sleepless nights).  Hope you are able to make a decision soon - but its an important one, so worth giving it as much thought and time as you need Violetsniff  love your mannequin!  Well done on losing the weight. I found out my BMI today at the pre-op, Im now officially overweight, first time ever (eek).  Whilst I need enough for my two new DIEP boobs, Ive taken the surgeon's advice not to lose any weight to the extreme! Decided I will have to loose a little bit of this excess weight during my mx recovery period in the summer, before I have the reconstruction. And of course will be keeping up the walking when Im fit enough.  moomy - THANK YOU for the ice cream photos.  Yum yum. Just got some Ben and Jerry's out of the freezer to have shortly (diet can wait) ronstar and Leolady56 - well done ladies, gold star for keeping up the group motivation and nice walks photos  I walked up the hill to the hospital and back down again (no photos - boring city centre). According to my Active 10 app I did 130 minutes walking today and 42 minutes were brisk - so not too shabby. And moomy you were right - my pulse was very high (walking and hospital anxiety) so they needed to take it again after 15 mins to check all okay.  Love to all maccie ramblers xxx

Posts.Content: Hi flossie25 so sorry to hear. ...  Such as difficult decision.   If you have a good BCN, do talk it through with her.   I have a had  mx and reconstruction and decided to do it again with my other side this time round.  For me if was a way of keeping some sort of new body normal. This time eventually going for DIEP rather than permanent implant - but it does mean several more surgery trips. But there are many ladies on here who decided on the no reconstruction route - and very happy with it. And fortunately these days if you decide now not ti have a reconstruction immediately, your can usually leave it open if you change your mind later. Im wide awake at stupid o'clock due to a combination of millions of things on my mind and a night of hot flashes. Oh the joy of being a woman on this bleeping journey.    Not enough time to do much walking at the mo, but will walk from work up to the hospital later today (about 30 mins up hill) then back into town as have my pre-op assessment Good luck honey xxx

Posts.Title: mixed emotions

Posts.Content: Hi lovely peeps Hope all of you waiting for results, operations and other staging points in your journey are finding some nice distractions. Ive just had a couple of days away after my SNB on Monday.  It was lovely, but a little too much for me (booked before this poop arrived). Im feeling exhausted if Im honest. So planning a duvet morning with some internet shopping for my groceries etc.   Trying to avoid the garden as my grass needs cutting,  my OH is away, and I really must not do it!  Kathryn.b  totally understand your feeling of not wanting to socialise much. Glad you are getting out and walking. It is good (even just a little one) on so many levels.  When I had my first operation (WLE) it was the height of the Beast from the East in February and I was completely housebound as we had deep snow.  The sun makes such a difference to my emotions. There is a lovely thread called walking back to happiness where people post about their walking.  Good luck on 1 May.. Do let me know how it goes. Im thinking about a DIEP for my MX (next stage).  Millie2018 go glad your scar is healing well and you are liking you new boob.  I felt so happy after I had my first MX, I couldnt believe how good it looked.  Fingers crossed for your results.  @lucy-b (cant seem to tag you).  How are you doing?. Have you got a date for your results?  xxx
Posts.Title: mixed emotions

Posts.Content: Hi lovely Kathryn.b   Its been a couple of days since you posted so hopefully you are feeling better emotionally (though those difficult issues will circulate in your mind). If not, I am thinking about you. It is such big stuff you are dealing with.   I had the post op blues yesterday.  Im feeling better this morning - new day, new things.  xxx

Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Big phew kathleen37.  I started on Letrozole a couple of weeks ago.  I asked my surgeon when I saw him for a follow up post surgery about bone density scan, and he said he would arrange it  Not sure if its a standard protocol everywhere (or even where I live), but worth asking about if they want you to take Letrozole. As you said, it gives you a baseline. Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX results back

Posts.Content: Hello SarahSS123. Others have given you very sensible advice and support on how you are feeling and what might happen if it is cancer  I just wanted to come on and share my experience - my lump was a mix of a benign cyst and cancer cells at the tip. The cancer bit was only 10 mm. Dont think they ever told me what size the whole lump was and I have a lumpy breast so it was picked up in a routine mammogram, rather than me finding it.   As you will have gathered, there are lots of different cancers and they need the biopsy to determine the type, stage and grade. That then determines treatment plan.  My original treatment plan, given it was a small cancer and lower grade but invasive, was for a lumpectomy (usually called WLE) followed by radiotherapy.  And that would have been completed months ago.  My treatment has taken longer due to my history (see my profile) and my family history.  So I am having a mastectomy next.   Fingers crossed for you.  Only thing that will help deal with your anxiety is to try keep busy from now until your results appointment.  With a young baby, I cant image that will be too difficult much of the time.  Do try and take someone along with you to the  results appointment, if you can as most of us dont take much in when results are given.   Hugs , and do come back on and let us know what they say. We are all here for you xxx
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy results - breast cancer

Posts.Content: And I confused cysts with lesions - mean to say my lump was a benign lesion/lump with 20mm cancer cells. You do learn something everyday (not that we ever wanted  to become an expert in this area ) xxx
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy results - breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Dreamthief for the link to the booklet. I hadnt found that one xx
Posts.Title: Tubular BC

Posts.Content: XjulieX  I have been diagnosed with grade 1 tubular too, so welcome to the rare cancer club!  The BCN said to me that this was one of the best cancers to have (if you can have a best one) as its very slow growing! And that its very treatable.  My initial treatment plan was the same as yours. But as this is my second cancer (see my profile) they are going down a more radical treatment route for me.  My previous cancer was a large DCIS a long time ago, so different, not related.  May just be an unlucky coincidence, though I am exploring the genetics side as we have BC in my family. Im very happy to help in any way. Dont google, there is very little about it out there.  I have had WLE (lumpectomy) in Feb (clear margins)  and a Sentinel Node Biopsy on Monday (all clear).  So feeling positive. Good luck and hugs from me xxx
Posts.Title: Tubular BC

Posts.Content: You too Julie. xx
Posts.Title: Tubular BC

Posts.Content: Beth567 Im so sorry that you are having to go through this. feeling down is so understandable. Its total pants, scary and from the sound of it you are experiencing a lot of discomfort.  So sending a virtual [[[[[[[[hug]]]]]]] Im just popping on to say Im having a mastectomy with a temp implant on Monday (just one side as Ive already had one on the other side). Then a double DIEP reconstruction at a later point. it was going to be Nov/December for that part but things have been delayed for me so Im not sure when. I think you are having a similar double DIEP reconstruction, so I thought I'd say hello. To be honest, Im not sure what my breast will look like after Monday as I assume given this is an interim step the surgeon isn't going to spend hours perfecting it.   Hopefully the discomfort will pass, and good luck with your journey too xxx

Posts.Title: No tears left

Posts.Content: Hello Loudwoman  Someone might come along with more recent experience, but I had a nipple created for my first MX 17 years ago. It was a fairly simple procedure. They took some skin from my groin and created a nipple from that.  Dont remember any problems or pain.  After the wound had healed, it was then tattooed to give it a more realistic colour.  This all happened a year after my MX so that everything had settled.   On close inspection, its clearly different from the other side. But I have been really happy with it. It helped give me very rough symmetry of appearance. Not perfect but enough for me to feel that I was the same as all my other lady friends. Odd shaped (aren't we all) but good enough to help me deal with my emotional grief. I was 37 at the time, and how I looked was important to my sense of self.  Now I am about the face a double MX, and having reconstruction but won't bother about the nipples this time.  I did get a prosthetic nipple made.  Lovely work, but never felt right (chucked it out years ago) Suggest you ask the BCN if you can see some photos and more info on how they do it. Im sure the procedures have changed since I had it done Good luck with whatever you decided xxx

Posts.Title: Good new’s

Posts.Content: Hi Tilla That does seem a long wait.  I was referred in April, saw the genetics nurse in May, then got the results in July (negative for BRAC1/2 - but strong family history so early (at 40) screening for the females in my family).   They didn't need to access any of my family medical records, they just asked me about all the females on the both sides of my parents family - any cancer, what    In May the nurse talked me through what the testing would involve and the implications of it, and then simply took a blood test. She said the blood testing was very thorough and would take 2-3 months. It took 2 months, and she rang me to give me the results. The testing times and process may vary of course across the country and between NHS trusts. I totally understand that you find this delay worrying  - the implications play on your mind.   Good luck and thinking for you
